item.title: CI/CD Best Practices
item.description:
CI/CD Best Practices

Continuous Integration and Continuous Delivery/Deployment practices for reliable software delivery.

Continuous Integration

Commit Frequently

Good: Multiple small commits per day
Bad: One large commit per week
  • Commit at least daily
  • Small, focused commits
  • Each commit should be complete and working
  • Avoid long-lived branches

Maintain a Single Source of Truth

  • One main branch (main/master)
  • All code lives in version control
  • Configuration in version control
  • Infrastructure as Code in version control

Automated Build on Every Commit

# Example: GitHub Actions
on:
 push:
 branches: [main]
 pull_request:
 branches: [main]

jobs:
 build:
 runs-on: ubuntu-latest
 steps:
 - uses: actions/checkout@v4
 - name: Build
 run: make build

Fix Broken Builds Immediately

  • Broken build = top priority
  • Don’t commit on a broken build
  • Revert if can’t fix quickly
  • Build status visible to all

Keep the Build Fast

Build Stage Target Time
Unit tests < 5 minutes
Full CI pipeline < 10 minutes
Integration tests < 20 minutes
  • Parallelise tests
  • Use caching
  • Optimise slow tests
  • Consider test splitting

Continuous Delivery Pipeline

Pipeline Stages

┌─────────┐ ┌──────┐ ┌──────────┐ ┌─────────┐ ┌────────────┐
│ Build │ → │ Test │ → │ Security │ → │ Package │ → │ Deploy │
└─────────┘ └──────┘ └──────────┘ └─────────┘ └────────────┘
 │
 ┌───────────────────┼───────────────────┐
 ▼ ▼ ▼
 ┌─────────┐ ┌─────────┐ ┌─────────┐
 │ Dev │ → │ Staging │ → │ Prod │
 └─────────┘ └─────────┘ └─────────┘

Build Stage

  • Compile code
  • Generate artefacts
  • Create container images
  • Tag with version/commit SHA

Test Stage

tests:
 unit:
 - Fast, isolated tests
 - No external dependencies
 - Run on every commit

 integration:
 - Test component interactions
 - May use test doubles
 - Run on every commit

 e2e:
 - Full system tests
 - Real dependencies
 - Run before deployment

 performance:
 - Load tests
 - Baseline comparisons
 - Run periodically or before release

Security Stage

  • Static Application Security Testing (SAST)
  • Dependency vulnerability scanning
  • Container image scanning
  • Secrets detection

Package Stage

  • Build immutable artefacts
  • Version everything
  • Store in artefact repository
  • Sign artefacts

Deploy Stage

  • Deploy to each environment identically
  • Environment-specific config only
  • Automated smoke tests
  • Automated rollback capability

Deployment Strategies

Rolling Deployment

Before: [v1] [v1] [v1] [v1]
During: [v2] [v1] [v1] [v1]
During: [v2] [v2] [v1] [v1]
During: [v2] [v2] [v2] [v1]
After: [v2] [v2] [v2] [v2]
  • Gradual replacement
  • No downtime
  • Easy rollback
  • Mixed versions during deployment

Blue-Green Deployment

 ┌─────────────────┐
 │ Load Balancer │
 └────────┬────────┘
 │
 ┌─────────┴─────────┐
 ▼ ▼
 ┌─────────┐ ┌─────────┐
 │ Blue │ │ Green │
 │ (v1) │ │ (v2) │
 │ ACTIVE │ │ IDLE │
 └─────────┘ └─────────┘
  • Two identical environments
  • Switch traffic instantly
  • Easy rollback (switch back)
  • Requires double resources

Canary Deployment

Traffic Split:
├── 95% → v1 (stable)
└── 5% → v2 (canary)

If healthy, gradually increase:
├── 90% → v1
└── 10% → v2
...
├── 0% → v1
└── 100% → v2
  • Gradual traffic shift
  • Real user testing
  • Fast rollback
  • Requires good monitoring

Feature Flags

if feature_flags.is_enabled("new_checkout"):
 return new_checkout_flow()
else:
 return old_checkout_flow()
  • Decouple deployment from release
  • A/B testing
  • Gradual rollout
  • Kill switch for features

Pipeline Best Practices

Pipeline as Code

# .gitlab-ci.yml or Jenkinsfile or .github/workflows/
stages:
 - build
 - test
 - security
 - deploy

build:
 stage: build
 script:
 - docker build -t app:$CI_COMMIT_SHA .
  • Version controlled
  • Peer reviewed
  • Auditable
  • Reproducible

Fail Fast

  • Run fastest tests first
  • Fail on first error
  • Parallelise independent jobs
  • Cache dependencies

Environment Parity

Environment Purpose Data Config
Dev Development Synthetic Dev
Test Testing Synthetic Test
Staging Pre-prod Anonymised prod Prod-like
Prod Production Real Prod
  • Same deployment process everywhere
  • Same artefacts everywhere
  • Only config differs

Artefact Promotion

Build Once, Deploy Many:

┌─────────┐ ┌─────────┐ ┌─────────┐ ┌─────────┐
│ Build │ ──▶ │ Dev │ ──▶ │ Staging │ ──▶ │ Prod │
│ app:abc │ │ app:abc │ │ app:abc │ │ app:abc │
└─────────┘ └─────────┘ └─────────┘ └─────────┘
 Same artefact promoted through environments
  • Build once, deploy many times
  • Artefacts are immutable
  • Configuration is external
  • Promotes tested code

Secrets Management

# Bad
database_password: "secret123"

# Good
database_password: ${VAULT_DB_PASSWORD}
  • Never commit secrets
  • Use secrets management (Vault, AWS Secrets Manager)
  • Rotate secrets regularly
  • Audit secret access

Testing Pyramid

 /\
 / \
 / E2E\ Few, slow, expensive
 /──────\
 / \
 /Integration\ Some, moderate
 /──────────────\
 / \
 / Unit Tests \ Many, fast, cheap
 /────────────────────\

Unit Tests

  • Test single units in isolation
  • Fast (milliseconds)
  • No external dependencies
  • High coverage

Integration Tests

  • Test component interactions
  • Moderate speed
  • May use test containers
  • Focus on boundaries

End-to-End Tests

  • Test complete workflows
  • Slow (seconds to minutes)
  • Real or near-real dependencies
  • Critical paths only

Monitoring and Feedback

Pipeline Metrics

  • Build duration
  • Build success rate
  • Test coverage
  • Deployment frequency

Deployment Metrics

  • Deployment duration
  • Deployment success rate
  • Rollback frequency
  • Time to recovery

Alerting

alerts:
 - name: DeploymentFailed
 condition: deployment_status == "failed"
 notify: [slack, pagerduty]

 - name: PipelineSlow
 condition: pipeline_duration > 15m
 notify: [slack]

Quick Reference

CI Checklist:
□ Single source repository
□ Automated build
□ Automated tests
□ Fast feedback (< 10 min)
□ Fix broken builds immediately
□ All tests pass before merge

CD Checklist:
□ Pipeline as code
□ Environment parity
□ Automated deployments
□ Artefact promotion
□ Secrets management
□ Rollback capability
□ Monitoring and alerting

item.title: DevOps Principles
item.description:
Core DevOps Principles

DevOps is a set of practices that combines software development (Dev) and IT operations (Ops) to shorten the development lifecycle while delivering features, fixes, and updates frequently and reliably.

The Three Ways

1. Flow (Systems Thinking)

Focus on the performance of the entire system, not just individual silos.

  • Optimise for global goals, not local departmental goals
  • Reduce batch sizes and work in progress
  • Eliminate constraints and bottlenecks
  • Never pass defects downstream
  • Create smooth, fast flow from development to operations to customer

2. Feedback (Amplify Feedback Loops)

Create fast, constant feedback at all stages.

item.title: Incident Management
item.description:
Incident Management Best Practices

Responding to, managing, and learning from incidents effectively.

Incident Lifecycle

┌──────────┐ ┌──────────┐ ┌──────────┐ ┌──────────┐ ┌──────────┐
│ Detect │ → │ Respond │ → │ Resolve │ → │ Review │ → │ Improve │
└──────────┘ └──────────┘ └──────────┘ └──────────┘ └──────────┘

Incident Severity Levels

Severity Impact Response Time Example
SEV1 Critical - Major outage Immediate (page) Complete service down
SEV2 High - Significant degradation < 30 min Partial outage, major feature broken
SEV3 Medium - Minor degradation < 4 hours Non-critical feature affected
SEV4 Low - Minimal impact Next business day Cosmetic issues

Severity Criteria

SEV1 - Critical

item.title: Infrastructure as Code
item.description:
Infrastructure as Code Best Practices

Managing infrastructure through code for consistency, repeatability, and automation.

Core Principles

Declarative over Imperative

# Declarative (preferred) - describe desired state
resource "aws_instance" "web" {
 ami = "ami-12345678"
 instance_type = "t3.micro"
 tags = {
 Name = "web-server"
 }
}

# Imperative - describe steps to achieve state
aws ec2 run-instances --image-id ami-12345678 --instance-type t3.micro
aws ec2 create-tags --resources i-xxx --tags Key=Name,Value=web-server
  • Declarative: what you want
  • Imperative: how to get there
  • Declarative is idempotent
  • Easier to understand and maintain

Idempotency

Running the same code multiple times produces the same result.

item.title: Monitoring and Observability
item.description:
Monitoring and Observability Best Practices

Understanding system behaviour through metrics, logs, and traces.

Observability vs Monitoring

Monitoring Observability
Known unknowns Unknown unknowns
Predefined questions Ad-hoc exploration
Dashboards and alerts Investigation and debugging
“Is it working?” “Why isn’t it working?”

Three Pillars of Observability

1. Metrics

Numerical measurements over time.

http_requests_total{method="GET", path="/api/users", status="200"} 1234
http_request_duration_seconds{quantile="0.99"} 0.245

Types:

Type Description Example
Counter Only increases Total requests
Gauge Can increase or decrease Current connections
Histogram Distribution of values Request latency buckets
Summary Quantiles over time p99 latency

2. Logs

Discrete events with context.
